study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) and Vitisin A could mitigate androgenetic alopecia (AGA) by inhibiting androgen receptors and preventing DHT-induced hair follicle damage.
results_summary: Both C3G and Vitisin A inhibited androgen receptors, reduced DHT-induced apoptosis in human dermal papilla cells, regulated growth factors, and improved hair follicle health in mice by preventing Wnt10b and β-catenin repression.
population_specificity: Human dermal papilla cells (in vitro) and mice (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of cyanidin-3-O-β-glucoside (C3G) in mitigating obesity-related complications through in vitro and in vivo studies.
results_summary: C3G demonstrated multiple biological benefits, including anti-obesity, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and metabolic regulatory effects by modulating genes and signaling pathways related to glucose, fatty acid, and lipid metabolism. The review concluded that C3G consumption may protect against obesity-related issues by maintaining body weight and metabolic balance.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies, likely animal and cellular models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of covalent and non-covalent interactions between myofibrillar protein (MP) and cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) on protein structure, binding sites, and digestion properties.
results_summary: The study confirmed covalent bonding between C3G and amino acid side chains in MP, identifying 30 modification sites. C3G significantly reduced MP digestibility, with covalent conjugates showing lower digestibility than non-covalent ones, particularly during intestinal digestion due to inhibited trypsin targeting sites.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using myofibrillar protein and C3G).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cyanidin, alone or combined with Trametinib, could improve pathology in muscular dystrophy by modulating the MAPK pathway and Nfix expression.
results_summary: Cyanidin combined with Trametinib reduced Nfix in myogenic cells but caused ectopic calcifications in dystrophic muscles. However, Cyanidin prevented Trametinib-induced calcifications in Diaphragm and Soleus, showing histological improvements.
population_specificity: Adult Sgca null mice (a model for muscular dystrophy)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) on amyloidogenic pathways, autophagy, tau phosphorylation, neuronal cell death, and synaptic plasticity in an Alzheimer's disease mouse model.
results_summary: C3G reduced amyloid-beta peptides, improved autophagy, mitigated tau phosphorylation, and enhanced synaptic function and plasticity in APPswe/PS1ΔE9 mice. It also modulated key signaling pathways, demonstrating neuroprotective effects.
population_specificity: APPswe/PS1ΔE9 transgenic mice (Alzheimer's disease model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) and its metabolite protocatechuic acid (PCA) could mitigate BPA-induced male reproductive toxicity.
results_summary: C3G and PCA increased testosterone and luteinizing hormone levels, improved sperm quality, alleviated apoptosis and oxidative stress in Leydig cells, and competitively bound to estrogen receptors, reducing BPA's harmful effects.
population_specificity: Male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential therapeutic and protective effects of Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) on inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), including ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn's disease (CD).
results_summary: C3G demonstrated antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, cytoprotective, and antimicrobial effects, inhibiting NF-κB pathway activation and activating the Nrf2 pathway. It also modulated gut microbiota and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines in UC and CD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel diseases (ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory effects of cyanidin, peonidin, and cyanidin-3-galactoside on tyrosinase activity and their potential as treatments for melanin-related diseases.
results_summary: Cyanidin showed the strongest inhibitory effect on tyrosinase, followed by peonidin and cyanidin-3-galactoside. The binding of these anthocyanins to tyrosinase induced conformational changes and fluorescence quenching, suggesting potential therapeutic applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: To investigate the role of cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) in renal ischemia/reperfusion injury and its potential mechanisms.
results_summary: C3G reduced renal dysfunction, tissue damage, apoptosis, and endoplasmic reticulum stress in mouse models, with the most pronounced effect at 200 mg/kg. It also inhibited oxidative stress and the JAK/STAT pathway, suggesting therapeutic potential for renal I/R injury.
population_specificity: Mouse models and in vitro cellular models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hemodynamic effects and potential cardiovascular benefits of Cyanidin 3-O-glucoside (C3G) in rats, focusing on blood flow, blood pressure, and angiogenesis.
results_summary: A single oral dose of C3G significantly increased blood flow and aortic Akt phosphorylation, while repeated administration for 14 days reduced mean blood pressure and increased angiogenesis markers in skeletal muscle.
population_specificity: Male rats (cremaster muscle arteriole and aortic tissue).
effective_dosage: Not specified (single and repeated oral doses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanism by which cyanidin inhibits adipocyte formation in 3T3-L1 preadipocytes.
results_summary: Cyanidin inhibited adipogenesis by downregulating adipogenic marker genes (PPARγ, C/EBPα, adiponectin, and aP2) without affecting cell viability. It increased intracellular Ca2+ via the PLC-IP3 pathway, suggesting a mechanism for its anti-obesity effects.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 preadipocytes (in vitro cell line study)
effective_dosage: 1-50 μM for adipogenesis inhibition; 30-100 μM for Ca2+ signaling

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the synergistic inhibitory effects of quercetin (QUR) and cyanidin-3O-sophroside (C3S) on ABCB1 (P-glycoprotein) activity and their potential to enhance chemotherapy efficacy in multidrug-resistant tumors.
results_summary: The study found that combining QUR and C3S resulted in stronger ATPase inhibition and reduced substrate transport by ABCB1, suggesting a synergistic inhibitory effect. Molecular docking and simulations supported simultaneous binding of QUR and C3S to ABCB1, with C3S occupying the central substrate binding site and QUR the "access tunnel."
population_specificity: In vitro and in silico models (not specified for human or animal subjects).
interactions: Synergistic interaction with quercetin (QUR); potential interaction with chemotherapy drugs via ABCB1 inhibition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin could prevent anxiety-like effects and neuroimmune dysregulation caused by withdrawal from the synthetic cathinone MDPV.
results_summary: Cyanidin prevented MDPV withdrawal-induced anxiety-like behavior and normalized elevated cytokine levels in the ventral tegmental area, as well as glutamate transporter mRNA levels in the amygdala. It showed no adverse effects on locomotor activity, aversion, or reward.
population_specificity: Rats undergoing MDPV withdrawal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of casein/cyanidin-3-O-glucoside nanoparticles (Cs-C3G) on gut microbiota disorders and metabolic health in high-fat-diet-fed mice.
results_summary: Cs-C3G reduced fat accumulation and liver oxidative stress, restored gut microbiota diversity, lowered the Firmicutes-to-Bacteroidetes ratio, increased beneficial microorganisms, and decreased opportunistic pathogens.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) on human gastric cancer cells and its underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: C3G demonstrated significant antiproliferative effects on gastric cancer cells, induced apoptosis, arrested the cell cycle in the G2/M phase, and inhibited cell migration by modulating ROS levels and signaling pathways like AKT, MAPK, STAT3, and NF-κB.
population_specificity: Human gastric cancer cells (MKN-45) and normal cells (unspecified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hepatoprotective ability of cyanidin (Cy) and investigate its mechanisms in mitigating acute liver injury induced by carbon tetrachloride (CCl4).
results_summary: Cyanidin significantly and dose-dependently ameliorated acute liver injury, reducing oxidative stress and inflammatory responses by enhancing antioxidant capacity and inhibiting NF-κB signaling. High-dose Cy showed effects comparable to silymarin, a positive control.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal model implied by CCl4-induced liver injury).
effective_dosage: High-dose and unspecified lower doses (exact amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the skin hydration effects of cyanidin-3,5-O-diglucoside (CDG) from rose petal extract and elucidate its molecular mechanism.
results_summary: CDG was identified as the most potent compound in rose petal extract for improving skin hydration by upregulating HAS2 expression through the GLK-MAP2K-MAPK signaling pathway. The study demonstrated significant hydration improvements in human skin and increased hyaluronic acid levels in keratinocytes and a 3D skin model.
population_specificity: Human participants (specific demographics not detailed) and in vitro models (keratinocytes, 3D human skin equivalent).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) and verbascoside (Verb) could protect retinal endothelial cells from high glucose-induced damage.
results_summary: C3G and Verb restored cell viability and reduced ROS levels in high glucose conditions, with the combination showing superior protection. They also preserved blood-retinal-barrier integrity and counteracted the down-regulation of tight junction proteins.
population_specificity: Human Retinal Endothelial Cells (HREC) in vitro

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer potential of cyanidin, focusing on its mechanisms of action against various cancer types.
results_summary: Cyanidin demonstrated anticancer activity by inhibiting RAS and MAPK pathways, activating caspases-3 and P-38, inducing cell cycle arrest, and altering redox status. It also enhanced chemotherapeutic effects on resistant cancer cells.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or in vivo studies implied but not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-tumor effect of cyanidin on glioma stem cells (GSCs) and its potential mechanism via the Wnt signaling pathway.
results_summary: Cyanidin significantly reduced cell viability in all GSC lines, regulated the Wnt signaling pathway, and altered protein levels of β-catenin, c-Myc, Twist1, and Snail1, suggesting an anti-tumor effect.
population_specificity: Seven glioma stem cell (GSC) lines (GBM2, GBM7, G166, G179, G144, GliNS2, and 293T cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin chloride (Cycl) has antidepressant effects in an LPS-induced depression model and to explore its potential mechanisms, including anti-inflammatory and neuroprotective actions in the hippocampus.
results_summary: Cycl significantly reduced depressive-like behaviors in LPS-challenged mice, suppressed hippocampal inflammation (TNF-α, IL-6, microglial hyperactivity), and restored expression of neurotrophic factors (GFAP, BDNF) and glutamate transporters (GLAST, EAAT2). These effects were also confirmed in cultured BV2 and U251 cells.
population_specificity: LPS-challenged mice and cultured BV2 and U251 cells.
effective_dosage: 20 or 40 mg/kg, administered intraperitoneally for 5 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether converting condensed tannins in chokeberries into cyanidin could enhance antioxidant activity and improve gut microbiota function.
results_summary: The study found that the optimal conversion treatment increased cyanidin yield by 1.50-fold, significantly boosting total and cellular antioxidant activity. It also positively influenced gut microbiota diversity.
population_specificity: In vitro (simulated digestion and fermentation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic effect of Chinese bayberry (containing Cyanidin-3-glucoside, C3G) on antibiotic-associated diarrhea (AAD) and elucidate its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Dried bayberry powder and C3G reduced diarrhea scores, improved gut microbiota diversity, decreased harmful bacteria, reduced inflammation, and restored intestinal tight junction proteins. C3G was identified as the likely primary active component.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with lincomycin-induced AAD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the absorption, transport, and anti-inflammatory effects of Cyanidin-3-glucoside (C3G) nanoliposomes in a Caco-2/RAW 264.7 co-culture model simulating intestinal inflammation.
results_summary: C3G nanoliposomes showed concentration-dependent uptake and transport, primarily via endocytosis, and significantly reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine expression (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6, IL-8) compared to free C3G, indicating stronger anti-inflammatory potential.
population_specificity: Caco-2/RAW 264.7 co-culture model (in vitro intestinal inflammation system).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antifibrotic properties of Cyanidin-3-galactoside (C3G) in mitigating silica particle-induced pulmonary fibrosis in mice.
results_summary: C3G treatment significantly reduced pulmonary fibrosis and cell infiltration, inhibited TGF-β/mTOR signaling via the NRF2/HO-1 pathway, and ameliorated epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in mice. The highest dose (400 mg/kg) showed the most pronounced effects, restoring key markers to control levels.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to silica particles (SP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) could mitigate the oxidative stress and lifespan reduction caused by polystyrene (PS) exposure in Caenorhabditis elegans, focusing on the role of the DAF-16 pathway.
results_summary: C3G treatment improved oxidative stress and extended lifespan in wild-type C. elegans by enhancing the DAF-16 pathway and its downstream antioxidant genes, particularly sod-3. These benefits were diminished in daf-16(-) mutants, indicating the pathway's critical role in C3G's effects.
population_specificity: Caenorhabditis elegans (wild-type and daf-16(-) mutant strains)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how thermal-induced interactions between β-conglycinin (7S) and cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) affect the bioaccessibility and antioxidant capacity of C3G.
results_summary: Thermal treatment increased the binding affinity of 7S-C3G complexes but decreased C3G bioaccessibility and showed an antagonistic effect on antioxidant capacity. Higher temperatures (65°C and 121°C) significantly reduced C3G bioaccessibility and amplified the antagonism between 7S and C3G.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).
interactions: Interaction with β-conglycinin (7S) noted, reducing bioaccessibility and antioxidant capacity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin 3-glucoside (C3G) stimulates hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) production in normal human dermal fibroblasts (NHDFs) and the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: C3G induced HGF production at mRNA and protein levels in NHDFs, activated β2-adrenergic receptor (β2AR) signaling, and increased intracellular cAMP levels, while cyanidin (aglycon of C3G) did not show these effects.
population_specificity: Normal human dermal fibroblasts (NHDFs) and HEK293 cells expressing β2AR.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of cyanidin-3-O-glucoside on Parkinson's disease (PD) in mice, focusing on its potential to modulate gut microbiota and metabolic pathways.
results_summary: Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside protected MPTP-induced PD mice, altered 67 metabolites linked to gut microbiota dysbiosis, and showed significant changes in 5 phyla and 22 genera. The study also identified correlations between gut microbiota and amino acid metabolism.
population_specificity: MPTP-induced Parkinson's disease mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanism by which Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) promotes bone formation and its potential therapeutic effects on osteoporosis.
results_summary: The study identified 34 upregulated and 17 downregulated genes in C3G-treated osteoblasts, with enrichment in lysosome and glycolipid biosynthesis pathways. Key genes (Atp6v0c, Cx3cl1, Ly6a) linked to osteoporosis were validated, suggesting C3G's potential in bone metabolism disorders.
population_specificity: MC3T3-E1 mouse osteoblasts

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective role of Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) on palmitic acid-induced pancreatic beta cell dysfunction and decipher its molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: C3G dose-dependently improved beta cell secretory function and reduced apoptosis by downregulating the PERK ER stress pathway, particularly the pro-apoptotic marker CHOP, as validated by RNA sequencing and siRNA experiments.
population_specificity: Primary isolated mouse islets and INS-1E cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how heat treatment and interactions with β-lactoglobulin (β-Lg) affect the stability, antioxidant capacity, and bioaccessibility of Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G).
results_summary: The study found that β-Lg protected C3G from heat-induced degradation, increased its antioxidant capacity by 4-10%, and significantly enhanced its bioaccessibility (up to 354.62% at 121°C). Non-covalent interactions between C3G and β-Lg were stronger at high temperatures (85-121°C).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
interactions: Interaction with β-lactoglobulin noted, enhancing stability and bioaccessibility of C3G.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) could overcome temozolomide resistance in glioma cells and explore the role of miR-214-5p in this process.
results_summary: C3G upregulated miR-214-5p, enhanced temozolomide's cytotoxic effect, and downregulated β-catenin and MGMT in resistant glioma cells. Combining C3G or miR-214-5p agomir with temozolomide significantly inhibited tumor growth.
population_specificity: TMZ-resistant LN-18/TR glioma cell line

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of cyanidin on human nucleus pulposus cells (HNPC) metabolism and its mechanism, particularly its role in attenuating high hydrostatic pressure-induced degradation.
results_summary: Cyanidin reversed the negative effects of high hydrostatic pressure (30 atm) on HNPC viability, proteoglycan synthesis, and cell matrix levels by blocking the Wnt/β-catenin signaling pathway. The effects of cyanidin were further reversed by SKL2001, an activator of the same pathway.
population_specificity: Human nucleus pulposus cells (HNPC) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolic impact of Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) on glucose metabolism and its underlying molecular mechanisms, particularly its anti-diabetic effects related to GLUT-1.
results_summary: C3G significantly reduced fasting blood glucose levels and increased glycogen synthesis in diabetic db/db mice, linked to upregulated GLUT-1 expression. In liver cells, C3G promoted glucose consumption via the Wnt/β-catenin-WISP1 pathway, an effect blocked by GLUT-1 inhibition.
population_specificity: Diabetic db/db mice and liver cell lines (HepG2, L02).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the neuroprotective effects of Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) and its metabolites, focusing on their ability to reduce Aβ aggregation, oxidative damage, and inflammation.
results_summary: C3G significantly suppressed Aβ aggregation, enhanced antioxidant capacity, improved memory in C. elegans, and reduced inflammation and oxidative damage in BV2 microglia cells. Its metabolites (Cy and OP) showed similar efficacy, while PCA had limited effects.
population_specificity: Transgenic Caenorhabditis elegans (Aβ model) and BV2 microglia cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) could improve impaired fertility in mice with ulcerative colitis by inhibiting inflammatory cytokines.
results_summary: C3G-treated mice showed improved body weight, colon length, sperm count, and reduced inflammation compared to the DSS-induced colitis group, suggesting C3G may protect fertility by suppressing inflammatory mediators.
population_specificity: Male mice with DSS-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of cyanidin-3-glucoside (C3G) and blueberry pectin (BP) complexes, particularly after high hydrostatic pressure (HHP) treatment, on mice with DSS-induced colitis.
results_summary: HHP-treated C3G-BP complexes significantly alleviated colitis symptoms in mice, including diarrhea, blood loss, and colon shortening. The mechanism involved reducing oxidative stress, modulating inflammatory factors, inhibiting the NF-κB pathway, and improving gut microbiota composition.
population_specificity: Mice with dextran sodium sulfate (DSS)-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) could alleviate polystyrene (PS)-induced toxicities and gut microbiome perturbations in C57BL/6 mice.
results_summary: C3G supplementation reduced tissue accumulation of PS, promoted fecal PS discharge, alleviated oxidative stress and inflammatory response, and modulated gut microbiome perturbations, including regulating functional bacteria linked to inflammation.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of high-pressure processing (HPP) on the binding capacity, stability, and antioxidant properties of cyanidin-3-glucoside (C3G) when complexed with rhamngalacturonan I (RG-I) pectin.
results_summary: HPP increased the binding rate between C3G and RG-I pectin by 32.8%, improved C3G stability (retention rates increased by 34.0% after heat treatment and 38.3% after simulated digestion), and maintained its antioxidant capacity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial potential and mechanisms of an acylated anthocyanin (C3G-LA) to guide its application as a food preservative.
results_summary: C3G-LA showed strong antibacterial activity against Staphylococcus aureus (MIC = 0.3125 mg/mL) and modest activity against Escherichia coli (MIC = 5 mg/mL). It disrupted membrane integrity, reduced intracellular ATP and pH, and altered cellular morphology, indicating membrane dysfunction.
population_specificity: Bacterial cultures (Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether cyanidin 3-O-β-galactoside from black chokeberry improves energy metabolism and cognitive function in aging mice.
results_summary: Cyanidin 3-O-β-galactoside alleviated brain glucose uptake decline, reduced neuronal damage in the hippocampus and cortex, decreased β-amyloid load, and improved performance in the Morris water maze test, suggesting neuroprotective effects via AKT-mediated energy metabolism regulation.
population_specificity: Aging mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the inhibitory mechanism of cyanidin-3-O-glucoside and (-/+)-catechin against tyrosinase using computational simulations and in vitro assessments.
results_summary: The study found that cyanidin-3-O-glucoside and (-/+)-catechin exhibited stable binding and oxidation by tyrosinase, with (-/+)-catechin showing substantial inhibition, suggesting potential for drug development against tyrosinase-associated diseases.
population_specificity: In vitro (mushroom and murine tyrosinases) and computational models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective role and mechanism of Cyanidin-3-glucoside (C3G) against high glucose-induced damage in human nucleus pulposus cells (HNPCs).
results_summary: C3G improved cell viability, reduced apoptosis, decreased ROS generation, and mitigated extracellular matrix degradation in HNPCs under high glucose conditions, primarily through activation of the Nrf2/HO-1 signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Human nucleus pulposus cells (HNPCs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) could alleviate oxidative stress in pancreatic islets under hyperglycemic conditions and explore its mechanism of action.
results_summary: C3G effectively reduced oxidative stress in pancreatic islet cells by activating mitophagy via the PINK1-PARKIN pathway, and it improved oxidative stress markers and fasting blood glucose levels in diabetic db/db mice.
population_specificity: Pancreatic islet cell line NIT-1 and diabetic db/db mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cyanidin-3-O-Glucoside (C3G) could protect human islets from post-transplant stress by reducing oxidative damage, inflammation, and amyloid formation.
results_summary: C3G improved cell viability, reduced amyloid formation, decreased ROS, and lowered inflammatory markers (IL-1β, NLRP3) while increasing autophagic activity (LC3) in human islets exposed to stressors like amylin, Aβ1-42, rapamycin, or H2O2. Some effects were statistically significant, while others showed trends without significance.
population_specificity: Human islets in vitro (laboratory setting).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the cardioprotective effects of dietary anthocyanins, specifically cyanidin-3-glucoside (C3G), persist after cessation of intake and to investigate the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that C3G-enriched diet reduced cardiac injury, oxidative stress, and mitochondrial damage after myocardial ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury, even a month after stopping the diet. The cardioprotection was linked to changes in gut microbiota rather than anti-inflammatory activity, as demonstrated by fecal microbiota transplantation transferring the protective effect.
population_specificity: Mice (including immune-deficient mice lacking mature B and T cells)
study_duration: 1 month of C3G-enriched diet followed by 1 month of washout with standard diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the gene expression profiles related to antioxidant, immune-related, and Alzheimer's disease pathways in mice treated with Cyanidin 3-O-glucoside (C3G) compared to controls.
results_summary: The study found that C3G upregulated six antioxidant genes and numerous immune-related genes in treated mice, suggesting potential antioxidant and immunomodulatory mechanisms. RT-PCR validation supported these findings, indicating C3G's possible therapeutic role in Alzheimer's disease.
population_specificity: Wild-type mice (C57BL/6J Jms) and an Alzheimer's mouse model (APPswe/PS1dE9 mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the intestinal protective effects of Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside and explore its potential mechanisms in regulating the intestinal mucosal immune system.
results_summary: Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside showed protective effects against intestinal diseases by repairing the intestinal wall, inhibiting inflammation, and regulating gut microbiota, though animal and clinical studies were noted as inadequate.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo and in vitro studies referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a novel nanocarrier (nanofibersolosome) for the colonic delivery of cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) to enhance its stability and efficacy in treating or preventing inflammatory bowel diseases.
results_summary: The nanofibersolosome formulations demonstrated superior stability, encapsulation efficiency, and C3G retention compared to the reference lipid formulation, leading to higher C3G delivery to the colon. Additionally, the nanofibersolosome samples showed enhanced antioxidant activity and promoted short-chain fatty acid generation.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (ratios of Fibersol®-2:lipoid S75 were 0.5-4).
study_duration: Not specified (storage and thermal treatments were evaluated at various temperatures and durations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antioxidant and cytoprotective effects of Cyanidin-3-glucoside (C3Ghv) on pancreatic β-cells under oxidative stress induced by streptozotocin (STZ).
results_summary: C3Ghv pre-treatment improved cell viability, reduced oxidative stress markers (ROS, nitric oxide, MDA), decreased apoptotic protein ratios (Bax/Bcl-2), and enhanced cell cycle progression (M2 phase) in STZ-treated pancreatic β-cells.
population_specificity: Rat insulinoma cells (RINm5F).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) could enhance the efficacy of cisplatin (DDP) while reducing its toxic effects on cervical cancer HeLa cells.
results_summary: C3G-DDP combination significantly increased oxidative stress and apoptosis in HeLa cells by altering antioxidant enzyme activity, ROS levels, and Nrf2 signaling pathway components, suggesting improved cancer cell susceptibility to DDP.
population_specificity: Cervical cancer HeLa cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective mechanism of cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) and its metabolite protocatechuic acid (PCA) against IQ-induced cytotoxicity in HepG2 cells.
results_summary: C3G and PCA alleviated IQ-induced cytotoxicity and apoptosis in HepG2 cells, with C3G being more effective. Proteomics and molecular docking revealed that C3G targets XIAP, inhibiting apoptosis by hindering IQ binding to the BIR3 domain.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (human liver cancer cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of cyanidin on osteoblast proliferation, differentiation, and bone resorption, as well as its potential mechanisms of action in bone health.
results_summary: Cyanidin increased osteoblast proliferation and differentiation, reduced apoptosis, and decreased RANKL-induced osteoclast formation and bone resorption. It also modulated mitochondrial and epigenetic markers, suggesting potential anabolic effects on bone.
population_specificity: Cultured human hFOB 1.19 osteoblasts and transgenic medaka fish.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (Cy3G) on human amniotic epithelial cells (hAECs) and investigate its mechanisms, particularly in modulating adipocyte differentiation.
results_summary: The study found that Cy3G treatment led to significant transcriptomic changes in hAECs, with 109 genes upregulated and 232 downregulated. Upregulated genes were linked to "response to muscle activity," while downregulated genes were associated with the cell cycle, suggesting Cy3G's potential role in modulating adipocyte differentiation.
population_specificity: Human amniotic epithelial cells (hAECs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside on cell cycle modulation in hepatic precancerous lesions induced by DEN/2-AAF in Wistar rats.
results_summary: Cyanidin administration mitigated hepatic precancerous lesions, reduced AFP levels, improved liver function, and modulated cell cycle-related RNA expressions, including decreasing MALAT1 and tubulin gamma 1 mRNA while increasing miR-125b. It also reduced GSTP foci and PCNA-positive nuclei.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with DEN/2-AAF-induced hepatic precancerous lesions.
effective_dosage: 10, 15, and 20 mg/kg/d, administered for four consecutive days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) enhances the antitumor effects of cisplatin (DDP) in cervical cancer cells and reduces chemotherapy-related adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that C3G alone inhibited HeLa cell proliferation by 34.98%, and its combination with DDP enhanced inhibition to 63.38%. The combination also modulated key signaling pathways (PI3K/AKT/mTOR) and induced apoptosis more effectively than either treatment alone.
population_specificity: Cervical cancer cells (HeLa cell line)
interactions: Enhanced antitumor activity when combined with cisplatin (DDP)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin could inhibit IL-17A/IL-17RA signaling, monocyte migration, and osteoclastogenesis in rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Cyanidin blocked IL-17A-induced monocyte migration, suppressed osteoclast formation, and downregulated key inflammatory markers via modulation of IL-17/p38 MAPK and IL-17A/STAT-3 signaling pathways. It also reduced RANKL expression and increased OPG in fibroblast-like synoviocytes.
population_specificity: Adjuvant-induced arthritic (AA) rats and their isolated monocytes/macrophages and fibroblast-like synoviocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cyanidin-3-O-β-glucoside (Cy-3-g) could attenuate pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) and explore its potential mechanism of action.
results_summary: Cy-3-g significantly reduced pulmonary artery pressure, right ventricular hypertrophy, and vascular remodeling in PAH rats, while also suppressing pro-inflammatory factors, blocking oxidative stress, and inhibiting smooth muscle cell proliferation via the TGF-β1/p38 MAPK/CREB pathway.
population_specificity: Rats with monocrotaline-induced PAH and human pulmonary arterial smooth muscle cells (SMCs) in vitro.
effective_dosage: 200 or 400 mg per kg of body weight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects and underlying mechanisms of Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) on osteoblast proliferation, differentiation, and mineralization, as well as its role in the ERK signaling pathway.
results_summary: C3G treatment enhanced osteoblast proliferation, mineralization, and the expression of osteocalcin (OC), while also increasing ERK phosphorylation, effects that were blocked by an ERK inhibitor. The findings suggest C3G promotes osteoblast activity via the ERK pathway, indicating potential for osteoporosis prevention and treatment.
population_specificity: Osteoblasts extracted from the hip joint of osteoporosis patients and MC3T3-E1 osteoblast cell line from mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether cyanidin-3-O-glucoside in red rice could inhibit the AGE-RAGE signaling pathway through in silico analysis.
results_summary: Cyanidin-3-O-glucoside showed potential as an inhibitor of AGE-RAGE interactions, with binding energies suggesting it could interfere with AGEs binding to RAGE, particularly with imidazole, argypirimidine, and pyrralline. The study concluded that cyanidin-3-O-glucoside might regulate pro-inflammatory and oxidative damage pathways.
population_specificity: In silico (computer-based) analysis (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effect of Cyanidin-3-glucoside (C3G) on myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: C3G reduced infarction area, mitigated pathological changes, inhibited oxidative stress, and suppressed ferroptosis-related protein expression in both in vivo and in vitro models. It also downregulated autophagy markers and promoted K11-linked ubiquitination of Beclin1, demonstrating potential cardioprotective effects.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury and H9c2 cells exposed to oxygen-glucose deprivation/reoxygenation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-allergic effects of cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) from black soybean hull extract (BSHE) on IgE-mediated type I allergic reactions.
results_summary: C3G inhibited degranulation in RBL-2H3 cells and suppressed passive cutaneous anaphylaxis (PCA) in mice, with intravenous administration showing stronger inhibition at lower doses compared to oral administration.
population_specificity: IgE-sensitized mice
effective_dosage: Oral: 200 μmol/kg C3G; Intravenous: 40 mg/kg C3G, 100 mg/kg BSHE (5.4% C3G)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antitumor mechanism of cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) in vivo using a Drosophila model of malignant tumors.
results_summary: C3G inhibited tumor growth and invasion, extended survival, and reduced autophagy in tumor cells and their microenvironment by inhibiting the JNK pathway. Combining C3G with chloroquine (CQ) showed better efficacy than either treatment alone.
population_specificity: Drosophila (fruit flies) with malignant tumors induced by activated oncogene Raf and loss-of-function mutations in the tumor suppressor scribble.
effective_dosage: Dose-dependent, but specific amounts not provided.
interactions: Enhanced efficacy when combined with chloroquine (CQ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effects of native and preheated milk proteins and bioactive compounds on the stability of cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) under acidic and neutral conditions.
results_summary: Both native and preheated milk proteins significantly protected C3G, with WPI preheated at 85°C showing the best effect under neutral conditions. Gallic acid provided the most significant protective effect by further reducing C3G's thermal degradation rate by 44.6%.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
interactions: Vitamin C accelerated C3G color loss, while EGCG and gallic acid improved thermal stability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how high hydrostatic pressure (HP) treatment affects the binding capacity, interaction, and antioxidant activity of cyanidin-3-glucoside (C3G) when combined with blueberry pectin (BP).
results_summary: HP treatment significantly improved the adsorption between C3G and BP, with the highest C3G concentration (382.1 ± 13.2 μg/mg for BP) achieved at a 1:2 mass ratio, 400 MPa pressure, and 15-minute holding time. HP altered the characteristics of C3G-BP complexes, enhancing electrostatic interactions and protecting C3G's antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (Cy3G) in inhibiting epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT), cell migration, and invasion in breast cancer cells, and to elucidate its underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: Cy3G inhibited EMT and significantly suppressed migration and invasion of breast cancer cells by upregulating KLF4 expression, which was mediated through downregulation of FBXO32, the E3 ligase of KLF4. KLF4 knockdown nullified Cy3G's effects, confirming its central role in the observed outcomes.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 and MDA-MB-468 breast cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of CY3D5G-rich extract on oxidative stress in D-galactose-induced accelerated aging in mice.
results_summary: CY3D5G-rich extract increased antioxidant enzyme activity, reduced oxidative stress markers, and modulated metabolic pathways linked to reduced ROS production in aged mice. Proteomic analysis identified significant changes in 243 proteins, suggesting CY3D5G's role in mitigating oxidative damage.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice with D-galactose-induced accelerated aging.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) against lipotoxicity and inflammation induced by free fatty acids in intestinal epithelial cells.
results_summary: C3G pre-treatment reversed inflammation and oxidative stress caused by palmitic acid in Caco-2 cells, modulating NF-κB and Nrf2 pathways. The results suggest C3G may be beneficial for intestinal inflammatory disorders.
population_specificity: In vitro study using Caco-2 human intestinal epithelial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) could alleviate high glucose-induced podocyte dysfunction and explore its potential mechanisms in diabetic nephropathy.
results_summary: C3G reversed high glucose-induced apoptosis, improved autophagy, and inhibited epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in podocytes by activating the SIRT1/AMPK pathway. These effects suggest C3G may protect against podocyte dysfunction in diabetic nephropathy.
population_specificity: MPC5 cells (a mouse podocyte cell line) under high glucose conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the potential anti-cancer effects of cyanidin 3-glucoside (RBC3G) from Thai rice bran on human prostate cancer (PC3) cells, focusing on its ability to inhibit epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and cancer cell motility.
results_summary: RBC3G inhibited EMT in PC3 cells by blocking cytoskeletal protein expression, reducing Smad/Snail signaling, and enhancing E-cadherin expression. It also suppressed matrix metalloproteinase-9 and nuclear factor-kappa B, slowing cancer cell migration and invasion.
population_specificity: Human prostate cancer (PC3) cells in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cytoprotective effects and molecular mechanisms of cyanidin-3-glucoside (C3G) against hydrogen peroxide-induced oxidative damage in HepG2 cells.
results_summary: C3G (2.5-10 μM) dose-dependently protected HepG2 cells from H2O2-induced oxidative damage by reducing ROS and MDA levels, enhancing antioxidant enzyme activities (SOD, GSH-Px, CAT), and modulating apoptosis-related protein expression. The protective effects were mediated via mitochondrial and external apoptotic pathways.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (human liver cancer cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin-3-glucoside (Cy3G) exerts metabolic benefits via modulation of GLP-1, leptin, insulin, and FGF21 pathways in mice.
results_summary: Cy3G reduced body weight gain and improved glucose tolerance in high-fat diet mice, linked to increased hepatic Fgf21 expression and related gene activity, but did not affect plasma leptin, insulin, or GLP-1 levels. Antibiotics altered Cy3G's glucose tolerance effects, suggesting gut microbiota involvement.
population_specificity: Male C57BL-6J mice (6 weeks old)
interactions: Broad-spectrum antibiotics altered Cy3G's effects on glucose tolerance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cyanidin-3-O-β-glucoside (Cy-3-G) could protect against alcohol-induced liver damage by suppressing inflammasome activation and NF-κB acetylation.
results_summary: The study found that Cy-3-G attenuated liver damage caused by alcohol and excess energy intake by mediating NAD+ homeostasis, stimulating SirT1 activity, and suppressing NF-κB acetylation and NLRP3 inflammasome activation, leading to reduced hepatic inflammation.
population_specificity: Hepatic cell lines (in vitro) and presumably animal models (implied by dietary provision, though not explicitly stated).
effective_dosage: Physiologically achievable dosage (specific amount not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the apoptotic effects of Cyanidin 3-O-Glucoside (C3G) on three osteosarcoma cell lines and explore its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: C3G induced apoptosis in osteosarcoma cell lines, with IC50 values of 110μg/ml for Saso-2 and G-292 cells and 140μg/ml for MG-63 cells. It upregulated PPARγ, P21, and Bax genes, with P21 protein overexpression confirmed by western blotting.
population_specificity: Three osteosarcoma cell lines (Saso-2, MG-63, G-292 clone A141B1).
effective_dosage: 110μg/ml for Saso-2 and G-292 cells, 140μg/ml for MG-63 cells (24-hour exposure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) could protect human corneal epithelial cells (HCECs) from LPS-induced inflammation and apoptosis by modulating the let-7b-5p-mediated HMGA2/PI3K/Akt pathway.
results_summary: C3G increased cell viability, reduced apoptosis and inflammation in HCECs exposed to LPS, and upregulated let-7b-5p while inhibiting the HMGA2/PI3K/Akt pathway. The protective effects of C3G were blocked when let-7b-5p was inhibited, confirming its role in the mechanism.
population_specificity: Human corneal epithelial cells (HCECs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cyanidin-3-O-glucoside (C3G) could alleviate non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) by promoting PINK1-mediated mitophagy.
results_summary: C3G administration reduced oxidative stress, NLRP3 inflammasome activation, and hepatic steatosis while improving glucose metabolism in NAFLD mice and human hepatocytes. These benefits were linked to enhanced PINK1/Parkin-mediated mitophagy, which was essential for C3G's effects.
population_specificity: Mice with high-fat diet-induced NAFLD and human AML-12/HepG2 hepatocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of cyanidin 3-O-glucoside (C3G) on T-cell function in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) compared to hydrochlorothiazide (HCT).
results_summary: C3G increased proportions of certain T-cell subsets (CD62Llo and CD62L-) and boosted cytokine production (TNFα and IFNγ) in SHR, suggesting positive immune modulation, while HCT suppressed T-cell function.
population_specificity: Male spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) and Wistar-Kyoto (WKY) rats.

study_goal: The study aimed to compare the impact of olanzapine, magnesium valproate, and lamotrigine as adjunctive treatments for anti-NMDAR encephalitis, focusing on neurotransmitter rebalance and clinical outcomes.
results_summary: Magnesium valproate and lamotrigine showed better outcomes than olanzapine, including lower PANSS scores, higher MoCA scores, and lower mRS scores, with improvements linked to decreased Glx/Cr ratios.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with anti-NMDAR encephalitis receiving standardized immunotherapy at Hunan Brain Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying the chemotherapeutic effects of cyanidin chloride (CyCl) in colorectal cancer cells, focusing on its impact on apoptosis, cellular proliferation, and signaling pathways (NF-κB and Nrf2).
results_summary: CyCl treatment induced apoptosis, inhibited cellular proliferation and colony formation in colon cancer cells, suppressed NF-κB signaling, and activated the Nrf2 pathway. Knockdown of Nrf2 inhibited CyCl's effects on NF-κB signaling and apoptosis, indicating functional crosstalk between Nrf2 and NF-κB.
population_specificity: Three colon cancer cell lines (HCT116, HT29, SW620).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review how neuroinflammation mediates levodopa-induced dyskinesia (LID) through NMDA receptor regulation and assess potential therapeutic targets.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that neuroinflammation and NMDA receptor activation may play a role in LID development, but it does not present specific findings on D-Aspartic Acid's effects.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease experiencing levodopa-induced dyskinesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method to identify NMDA-2A ligands from natural products for potential use in Alzheimer's disease treatment.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a novel affinity stationary phase to screen NMDA-2A ligands, identifying crocetin as a compound that binds to NMDA-2A and increases its protein levels in a cellular AD model.
population_specificity: Cellular model of Alzheimer's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether antenatal memantine treatment could prevent heart injury in neonatal offspring exposed to intrauterine hypoxia.
results_summary: Intrauterine hypoxia caused mitochondrial dysfunction and structural abnormalities in offspring hearts, which were improved by antenatal memantine treatment. NMDAR activation by hypoxia led to mitochondrial damage, and blocking NMDARs attenuated these effects.
population_specificity: Pregnant rats and their neonatal offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of D-Aspartic Acid (D-Asp) on pyroptosis in human gingival fibroblasts (HGFs) induced by HMGB1 and explore its potential protective mechanism.
results_summary: D-Asp (1-30 mM) reduced cell membrane permeability and suppressed the expression of pyroptosis-related markers (NLRP3, caspase-1, GSDMD, IL-1β, IL-18) in HGFs, indicating competitive antagonism against HMGB1. The study suggests D-Asp may help prevent pyroptosis and treat peri-implantitis.
population_specificity: Human gingival fibroblasts (HGFs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of the ROS-TXNIP-NLRP3-NR2B pathway in type 2 diabetic neuropathic pain (DNP) and the potential therapeutic effects of targeting this pathway.
results_summary: The study found that spinal ROS contributes to type 2 DNP via the TXNIP-NLRP3-NR2B pathway, and interventions like ROS scavenger PBN or TXNIP knockdown alleviated nociceptive hypersensitivity and reduced related protein levels in DNP rats and cell cultures.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with induced type 2 diabetes and diabetic neuropathic pain, and BV2/PC12 cells in high-glucose conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of NMDA receptors, specifically through D-Aspartic Acid-related mechanisms, in heat-sensitization response and its impact on moxibustion efficacy for cerebral infarct rehabilitation.
results_summary: Inhibition of NMDA receptors with CPP significantly reduced heat-sensitization response and negatively affected moxibustion's rehabilitation efficacy in cerebral infarct rats, suggesting NMDA receptor activation plays a positive role in ischemic stroke recovery.
population_specificity: Cerebral infarct rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of the NMDAR/NO pathway in the anticonvulsive effects of lenalidomide on PTZ-induced seizures in mice.
results_summary: Lenalidomide at 10 and 20 mg/kg significantly elevated PTZ-induced seizure thresholds. The anticonvulsive effects were reversed by NO synthase inhibitors and the NMDAR antagonist MK-801, but not by the NMDAR agonist D-serine.
population_specificity: NMRI mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether D-Aspartic Acid (D-Asp) could protect against the toxic effects of ethane dimethane sulfonate (EDS) on rat testis, particularly focusing on Leydig cell damage and oxidative stress.
results_summary: Pre-treatment with D-Asp prevented EDS-induced Leydig cell destruction, maintained normal testosterone levels, reduced oxidative stress (TBARS levels), and preserved testicular morphology and sperm production.
population_specificity: Male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the incidence of ovarian dermoid cysts associated with paraneoplastic encephalitis syndrome due to NMDA receptor antibodies among women undergoing surgical resection of dermoid cysts.
results_summary: The study found that anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis is a rare complication (0.85%) of ovarian dermoid cysts, occurring in both younger and older women with varying cyst sizes. Both affected patients recovered without significant neurological sequelae after treatment.
population_specificity: Women who underwent surgical resection of pathology-proven ovarian dermoid cysts between 2008 and 2019.

study_goal: The researchers were investigating a rare case of anti-NMDA-R encephalitis in a patient with autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 3, not directly studying D-Aspartic Acid.
results_summary: The study reported a case of anti-NMDA-R encephalitis in a patient with autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 3, highlighting early detection and steroid pulse therapy leading to full recovery. No direct findings on D-Aspartic Acid were mentioned.
population_specificity: A 39-year-old patient with autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 3 and anti-NMDA-R encephalitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Zn2+ and H+ in NMDA receptor activity related to depression and develop a dual-color fluorescent probe (DNP) to monitor these changes in living mouse brains.
results_summary: The study found that the DNP probe successfully tracked synchronous increases in Zn2+ and H+ in PC12 cells under oxidative stress and revealed simultaneous reductions of Zn2+ and pH in the brains of mice with depression-like behaviors, suggesting NMDA receptor involvement.
population_specificity: Mice with depression-like behaviors and PC12 cells under oxidative stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the short-term effects of D-Aspartic Acid on serum biomarkers of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis and athletic performance in male climbers.
results_summary: The study found that D-Aspartic Acid did not significantly affect testosterone, free testosterone, or luteinizing hormone levels, nor did it influence other parameters linked to athletic performance or health status. Only minor changes in sex hormone binding globulin and cortisol were observed, which were not treatment-specific.
population_specificity: Male climbers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether NMDA (N-methyl-d-aspartic acid) induces brain edema and if low-intensity ultrasound (LIUS) or NMDAR antagonists can mitigate this effect.
results_summary: NMDA induced brain edema similar to oxygen-glucose deprivation (OGD), while DHPG did not. NMDAR antagonists (MK-801, ketamine) and LIUS effectively reduced edema by inhibiting NMDAR phosphorylation.
population_specificity: Rat hippocampal slices (in vitro model).
effective_dosage: Ultrasound administered at 30, 50, or 100 mW/cm² for 20 minutes.
study_duration: 20 minutes of ultrasound treatment before edema induction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a case of anti-NMDA-R encephalitis associated with autoimmune polyglandular syndrome (APS) and explore potential shared autoimmune mechanisms.
results_summary: The study reported a case of a 58-year-old woman with APS and anti-NMDA-R encephalitis, showing clinical improvement after surgical removal of an adnexal mass and resolution of anti-NMDA-R antibodies post-surgery. The findings suggest a possible shared autoimmune pathophysiology between APS and anti-NMDA-R encephalitis.
population_specificity: A 58-year-old woman with Graves' disease, thyrotoxicosis, type 1 diabetes mellitus, and anti-NMDA-R encephalitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of EGb 761 (a Ginkgo biloba extract) on GluN2B expression in the inferior colliculus following sodium salicylate-induced ototoxicity, not specifically D-Aspartic Acid.
results_summary: The study found that EGb 761 reduced GluN2B protein expression in the inferior colliculus compared to the sodium salicylate-only group, suggesting a regulatory role in salicylate-induced ototoxicity. No significant differences in auditory brainstem response thresholds were observed among groups.
population_specificity: Seven-week-old Sprague Dawley rats (n=24)
effective_dosage: EGb 761 administered orally at 40 mg/kg for 5 consecutive days; sodium salicylate injected at 350 mg/kg once.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a water-soluble lipopolymer (WSLP) in delivering siRNA targeting NR2B to PC12 cells and its potential to relieve chronic inflammatory pain in rats.
results_summary: WSLP effectively protected siRNA from degradation, showed low cytotoxicity, and significantly reduced NR2B transcriptional and protein levels by 50% and 55%, respectively. Intrathecal injection of WSLP/NR2B-siRNA complexes in rats significantly reduced NR2B protein expression (58%) and relieved inflammatory pain over 3-5 days.
population_specificity: PC12 cells and rats with chronic inflammatory pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of the N-methyl-D-aspartic acid receptor (NMDAR) antagonist, memantine, on SK-N-SH cell apoptosis caused by chronic ethanol exposure.
results_summary: Chronic ethanol exposure reduced neuronal cell viability and induced apoptosis in SK-N-SH cells, linked to increased intracellular calcium concentration via NMDAR expression. Memantine treatment reduced ethanol-induced apoptosis, suggesting potential for treating alcoholic dementia.
population_specificity: SK-N-SH human neuroblastoma cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether D-Aspartic Acid (DAA) could alter basal testosterone levels and affect training outcomes in resistance-trained men over 3 months.
results_summary: DAA supplementation did not change testosterone levels but led to a 16% reduction in estradiol. Both DAA and placebo groups showed similar improvements in strength and muscle hypertrophy, with no additional benefits from DAA.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained men aged 18-36 who had been training regularly for at least 2 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of repeated D-Aspartic Acid treatment on neuropathic pain, cognitive/emotional dysfunctions, β-amyloid protein accumulation, and steroid levels in a mouse model of chronic pain.
results_summary: D-Asp treatment reduced abnormal behaviors, normalized β-amyloid protein expression, and significantly increased steroid levels in the prefrontal cortex and hippocampus of neuropathic mice.
population_specificity: Mice with spared nerve injury (SNI)-induced neuropathic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of D-Aspartic Acid on sperm quality, fertility, and hatchability in male broiler breeders.
results_summary: D-Aspartic Acid at 200 mg/kg BW significantly improved fresh and post-thawed sperm quality, fertility, and hatchability compared to other doses, with no significant adverse effects on sperm viability.
population_specificity: Male broiler breeders (55-week-old roosters)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the psychiatric aspects of anti-NMDAR encephalitis and present a case report of a patient with pure psychiatric manifestations of the disease.
results_summary: The study highlights that anti-NMDAR encephalitis often presents with psychiatric symptoms initially, leading to misdiagnosis and unnecessary antipsychotic treatment. Immune suppressive therapy was effective in most cases, though the connection between anti-NMDAR antibodies and psychotic disorders remains unclear.
population_specificity: Patients with anti-NMDAR encephalitis, particularly those presenting with psychiatric symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to design and evaluate novel Pin1 inhibitors based on glutamic acid or aspartic acid scaffolds for potential cancer therapy.
results_summary: Glutamic acid derivatives with cycloalkylamino and phenylthiazole groups showed potent Pin1-inhibitory activity comparable to known inhibitor VER-1, with steric interactions of cyclic alkyl amine moieties enhancing inhibitory effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of N-methyl-D-aspartic acid receptor 1 (NMDAR1) in NLRP3-mediated inflammatory damage following intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH).
results_summary: The study found that NMDAR1 expression and phosphorylation increased after ICH, promoting NLRP3 inflammasome activation and IL-1b release, which was reversed by the NMDAR antagonist MK801. Hemin treatment enhanced NMDAR1-NLRP3 binding, suggesting NMDAR1's pivotal role in inflammatory damage.
population_specificity: Mice with induced intracerebral hemorrhage and cultured microglial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of miR-217 in vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) phenotype transition under homocysteine exposure and its effect on atherosclerotic plaque formation, with NMDAR as a potential target.
results_summary: The study found that miR-217 mimic inhibited VSMC proliferation and migration under homocysteine treatment, down-regulated NMDAR protein expression, and restored CREB-PGC-1α signaling, while miR-217 inhibitor had opposing effects. PGC-1α restoration suppressed VSMC proliferation via NOX1 degradation and ROS reduction.
population_specificity: Human aortic vascular smooth muscle cells (HA-VSMCs) and rat aortic VSMCs.
effective_dosage: Homocysteine doses ranged from 0 to 8 × 10^(-4) mol/L.

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the ketamine dose-dependency of ketamine-induced cystitis (KC) in a rat model, focusing on urinary tract dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found that higher ketamine doses led to decreased voiding intervals and bladder capacity, increased fibrosis, and submucosal apoptosis, suggesting fibrosis plays a key role in KC.
population_specificity: Female Sprague-Dawley rats (10-week-old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether agmatine protects Müller cells from glucose-induced damage and to explore the underlying mechanisms, including the role of NMDA receptor suppression.
results_summary: Agmatine reduced lactate dehydrogenase activity and tumor necrosis factor-α mRNA expression, inhibited glucose-induced apoptosis, and suppressed MAPK phosphorylation in Müller cells. These protective effects were blocked by NMDA, suggesting agmatine's benefits are mediated via NMDA receptor suppression.
population_specificity: Müller cells (retinal glial cells) exposed to high glucose concentrations in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of modulating spinal NMDAR activation (potentially involving D-Aspartic Acid) on morphine-induced analgesic tolerance.
results_summary: The study suggests chronic morphine treatment may worsen spinal NMDAR activation and sensitization, potentially accelerating morphine tolerance; NMDAR inhibition could alleviate tolerance development.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or preclinical model based on context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the metabolism and disposition of lanicemine (AZD6765), an NMDA channel blocker, in healthy male subjects after a single intravenous dose.
results_summary: Lanicemine was found to be a low-clearance compound, with the unchanged drug and metabolites predominantly eliminated via urinary excretion. The major circulating component was lanicemine itself, with 10 metabolites identified, none exceeding 4% of total radioactivity in plasma or urine.
population_specificity: Six healthy male subjects
study_duration: Single dose (no duration specified beyond sample collection)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether atorvastatin (ATV) treatment affects the GluN1 and GluN2B subunits of the N-methyl-D-aspartic acid receptor in the somatosensory cerebral cortex following ischemia, and its role in neuroprotection.
results_summary: ATV treatment improved neurological recovery, prevented neuronal damage, restored protein staining, and prevented spatial learning and memory deficits post-ischemia. It also preserved GluN1/PSD-95 and GluN2B/PSD-95 colocalization and BDNF levels, with GluN2B inhibition reversing these benefits.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats subjected to cerebral ischemia-reperfusion or sham operation.
effective_dosage: 10 mg/kg every 24 hours for 3 consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the clinical manifestations, immunotherapeutic response, and prognosis of anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis.
results_summary: The study found that anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis presents with psychiatric symptoms, memory loss, epilepsy, and movement disorders, and timely treatment can yield a favorable prognosis.
population_specificity: Seven patients with anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis.

study_goal: The study investigated the effects of TRPV1 agonists (capsaicin and SA13353) on retinal injury induced by NMDA in rats, not D-Aspartic Acid.
results_summary: The study found that capsaicin and SA13353 almost completely prevented retinal ganglion cell loss induced by NMDA in rats, with protection mediated via TRPV1, CGRP, and tachykinin NK1 receptors.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats and B6.Cg-TgN(Thy1-CFP)23Jrs/J transgenic mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective and anti-inflammatory effects of simvastatin, particularly its interaction with NMDAR1 (N-methyl-D-aspartic acid receptor 1), in a Parkinson's disease cell model.
results_summary: Simvastatin reduced 6-OHDA-induced increases in LDH, glutamate, and proinflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6) in PC12 cells, with effects comparable to NMDAR1 silencing. This suggests NMDAR1 modulation may underlie simvastatin's anti-inflammatory mechanisms.
population_specificity: PC12 (pheochromocytoma-12) cells treated with 6-OHDA to model Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether electroacupuncture (EA) could modulate NMDA receptor expression (specifically NR 1 and NR 2 B subunits) in the spinal cord of rats with chronic constrictive injury (CCI) to alleviate neuropathic pain.
results_summary: EA significantly downregulated NR 1 protein and mRNA expression in the spinal cord of CCI rats, correlating with pain relief, but had no significant effect on NR 2 B expression.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats with induced chronic constrictive injury (CCI) of the sciatic nerve.
effective_dosage: EA stimulation at 2 Hz, 1-3 mA (increasing 1 mA every 10 min) for 30 min daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which endogenous IL-1β alters glutamatergic synaptic transmission in the spinal dorsal horn in rats with neuropathic pain.
results_summary: The study found that endogenous IL-1β enhances glutamate release from primary afferent terminals and non-NMDA glutamate receptor activities in postsynaptic neurons in the spinal dorsal horn, mediated by the MyD88 and neutral sphingomyelinase/ceramide signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Rats with neuropathic pain induced by ligation of the L5 spinal nerve.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular mechanisms by which NMDA receptor activation affects GABAA receptor plasticity, specifically focusing on δ subunit expression in hippocampal neurons.
results_summary: Prolonged NMDA treatment reduced surface and total δ subunit expression in hippocampal neurons, diminished tonic current, and decreased neurosteroid modulation, while synaptic inhibition remained unaffected. These effects were mediated by Ca²⁺ entry and ERK1/2 activation.
population_specificity: Cultured hippocampal neurons from epileptic animals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the disease course and treatment outcomes in a case of NMDA receptor antibody-associated encephalitis with delayed therapy.
results_summary: The study found that recovery in NMDA receptor encephalitis can be severely delayed and non-linear, with a surprising recovery occurring 18 months after rituximab treatment and 30 months after symptom onset. Serum antibodies were unreliable markers of disease activity.
population_specificity: A 16-year-old girl with NMDA receptor antibody-associated encephalitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells (ipRGCs) are resistant to NMDA-induced excitotoxicity.
results_summary: The study found that ipRGCs were resistant to NMDA-induced excitotoxicity, unlike other retinal ganglion cells, and this resistance did not depend on PI3K/AKT or JAK/STAT signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether KN-93, a calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II inhibitor, could mitigate N-methyl-D-aspartic acid-induced neuronal injury in rat cortical neurons.
results_summary: KN-93 treatment increased cell activity, reduced apoptosis, decreased lactate dehydrogenase leakage, and lowered intracellular Ca(2+) concentrations. The effect was dose-dependent, with 1.0 μM KN-93 showing the most significant neuroprotective impact, likely due to downregulation of caspase-3 and calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II expression.
population_specificity: Primary cultured cerebral cortical neurons from Sprague-Dawley neonatal rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gintonin, a component of ginseng, enhances NMDA receptor activity and long-term potentiation (LTP) via LPA receptor activation, potentially explaining ginseng's memory-improving effects.
results_summary: Gintonin enhanced NMDA receptor-mediated ion currents and LTP in a concentration-dependent manner, effects blocked by LPA receptor antagonists and other inhibitors, suggesting a role in memory-related brain functions.
population_specificity: Xenopus oocytes expressing rat NMDA receptors and cultured hippocampal neurons/rat hippocampal slices.

study_goal: The researchers investigated the protective mechanism of ACTH against brain damage in an infantile spasm rat model induced by N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA).
results_summary: Prenatal stress exposure worsened seizures, while ACTH treatment reduced and delayed seizure onset. Key proteins involved in cytoskeleton, synapses, and energy metabolism were identified as part of ACTH's mechanism.
population_specificity: Neonate rats and five infantile spasm patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether D-Aspartic Acid (D-Asp) modulates sex hormone levels in male frogs by regulating P450 aromatase activity and its effects on testosterone and estradiol levels during different reproductive phases.
results_summary: D-Asp administration increased brain P450 aromatase expression, estradiol levels, and ERα expression while decreasing testosterone and androgen receptor expression in reproductive-phase frogs, but had no effect in post-reproductive frogs. The findings suggest D-Asp plays a role in regulating estradiol levels in the frog brain.
population_specificity: Male frogs during reproductive and post-reproductive phases of the breeding cycle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of NMDA receptor blockade (via memantine) on collagen-induced arthritis in mice, focusing on its potential to modulate inflammation and immune responses.
results_summary: Memantine significantly improved arthritis outcomes by reducing synovitis and erosions, while upregulating regulatory T cells. Other GluR antagonists (AIDA and KA) showed no effect.
population_specificity: DBA/1 mice with collagen-induced arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of pre- and postsynaptic NMDA receptors in controlling increased glutamatergic input in the spinal cord induced by chronic systemic morphine administration.
results_summary: Chronic morphine increased glutamatergic input in the spinal cord, which was attenuated by blocking NMDARs and inhibiting PKC. Postsynaptic NMDAR activity was impaired by morphine, while presynaptic activity was potentiated, contributing to opioid hyperalgesia and analgesic tolerance.
population_specificity: Rat spinal cord dorsal horn neurons

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between nitric oxide-mediated cell death in human periodontal ligament fibroblasts and the NMDA receptor antagonist MK801.
results_summary: The study found that nitric oxide (via SNP) reduced cell viability in a concentration-dependent manner and increased apoptotic markers (Bax, cytochrome c). NMDA receptor antagonist MK801 showed a synergistic effect with SNP in inducing apoptosis.
population_specificity: Human periodontal ligament fibroblasts (PDLFs)
effective_dosage: SNP concentrations ranged from 0 to 4 mM; MK801 was used at 200 µM.

study_goal: The researchers were comparing the antinociceptive effects and side effects of three N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor antagonists (ketamine, norketamine, and traxoprodil) in rat models of acute and chronic pain.
results_summary: All three antagonists showed dose-dependent antinociception in acute pain and relief of chronic pain symptoms, with ketamine being the most potent. Traxoprodil demonstrated a clear separation between therapeutic effects and side effects, making it a promising alternative to ketamine for chronic neuropathic pain.
population_specificity: Rat models of acute antinociception and chronic neuropathic pain (spared nerve injury).
study_duration: 3 hours per day for 5 consecutive days in the chronic pain model.

study_goal: The study does not investigate D-Aspartic Acid; it focuses on the effects of cannabinoid receptor agonists (specifically CB2 receptor activation) on cancer pain and NR2B receptor expression in mice.
results_summary: The study found that intrathecal administration of the CB2 receptor agonist JWH015 attenuated tumor-evoked pain behaviors in mice, likely by reducing NR2B-dependent activity in the spinal cord. The effect was dose-dependent and blocked by the CB2 antagonist AM630.
population_specificity: C(3)H/Hej mice with induced bone cancer pain.
study_duration: Assessments were made up to 72 hours post-administration.

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate whether curcumin exhibited neuroprotective and antioxidant activity via enhanced RANTES expression by astrocytes in cortical neuron cultures, not D-Aspartic Acid.
results_summary: The study found that curcumin enhanced RANTES expression in astrocytes, inhibited iNOS expression, and improved neuronal survival in NMDA toxicity and long-term cultures via PI3K/MAPK pathways. No findings related to D-Aspartic Acid were reported.
population_specificity: Primary cultures of cortical neurons and astrocytes from Sprague-Dawley rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the molecular mechanisms by which cholesterol modulates Aβ-induced Tau cleavage in cultured hippocampal neurons, focusing on the role of N-methyl-d-aspartic acid receptors.
results_summary: The study found that cholesterol reduction in mature neurons decreased NR1 subunit membrane presence and increased large NR1, NR2A, and NR2B subunit clusters, suggesting synaptic changes underlie cholesterol's modulation of Aβ-induced toxicity. N-methyl-d-aspartic acid receptor inhibitors were shown to play an essential role in cholesterol-mediated Aβ-dependent calpain activity and Tau cleavage.
population_specificity: Cultured hippocampal neurons (in vitro cellular model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of stress and stress-alcohol interactions on NMDA receptors in the brains of WKY and WIS rat strains.
results_summary: The study found that voluntary alcohol consumption increased NMDA receptors in the hippocampus and basolateral amygdala in both rat strains, while chronic stress increased NMDA receptors in the prefrontal cortex, caudate putamen, and nucleus accumbens in WKY rats. Alcohol co-treatment with stress reversed stress-induced NMDA receptor changes in the basolateral amygdala but not in the hippocampus.
population_specificity: Wistar-Kyoto (WKY) and Wistar (WIS) rat strains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the distribution of D-aspartic acid (D-Asp) and related enzyme activities in frog tissues, as well as the effects of D-Asp administration on these enzymes.
results_summary: High concentrations of free D-Asp were found in frog testes, liver, and Harderian gland. D-Asp administration increased D-AspO activity but not D-AAO or L-AAO, suggesting D-AspO plays a role in regulating D-Asp levels.
population_specificity: Frog (Rana esculenta) tissues

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether D-Aspartic Acid (D-Asp) plays a role in learning and memory processes in rats.
results_summary: Oral administration of sodium D-aspartate significantly improved cognitive performance in rats, as evidenced by faster platform location in the Morris water maze. Treated rats showed a 2.7-fold increase in hippocampal D-Asp levels, correlating with enhanced cognitive capability.
population_specificity: Rats (24 total, divided into treated and control groups).
effective_dosage: 40 mM sodium D-aspartate (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the relationship between learning and memory ability (LMA) and hippocampal NMDA expression in burn rats with depression.
results_summary: The study found that burn combined with depression reduced LMA, possibly due to decreased NMDA expression in the dentate gyrus. Escape latency in the water maze test was prolonged in burn and depression groups compared to controls.
population_specificity: Wistar rats (burn, depression, burn + depression, and healthy control groups).

study_goal: The researchers sought to describe hospice medical directors' practice patterns and experiences regarding the use and discontinuation of NMDA receptor antagonists (including memantine, an NMDA antagonist related to D-Aspartic Acid) in end-stage dementia patients.
results_summary: A subset of hospice medical directors reported clinical benefits from NMDA receptor antagonists, including stabilization of cognition (22%), reduced challenging behaviors (28%), and improved caregiver outcomes (20%). However, discontinuation led to accelerated cognitive/functional decline (30%) and challenging behaviors (32%) in some patients.
population_specificity: Hospice patients with end-stage dementia meeting Medicare hospice criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between D-Aspartic Acid and testicular activity, specifically its effects on testosterone levels, c-kit receptor protein, tyrosine kinase activity, and PCNA in the reproductive cycle of Podarcis s. sicula.
results_summary: The study found that D-Aspartic Acid significantly accumulated in the testes, increasing testosterone levels, enhancing c-kit receptor protein expression, and activating tyrosine kinases. It also induced PCNA expression, suggesting a functional relationship between these molecules mediated by D-Asp.
population_specificity: Lizard (Podarcis s. sicula) testes during the reproductive cycle.
study_duration: Observations made up to 15 hours post-injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the extent of oxidative stress induced by D-Aspartic Acid in the testis of prepubertal rats.
results_summary: D-Aspartic Acid significantly increased oxidative stress markers (reactive oxygen species, malondialdehyde, hydroperoxide) and altered mitochondrial function in the testis, suggesting potential oxidative perturbations.
population_specificity: Prepubertal rats
effective_dosage: 100 and 500 mg/kg body weight per day, intraperitoneal

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of the NMDAR antagonist MK-801 on NMDAR subunit expression in parvalbumin-immunoreactive interneurons and pyramidal neurons in the prefrontal cortex of young adult rats.
